response.answer_text: From Online Etymology: homeboy (n.) "person from one's hometown," 1940s, African-American vernacular, also originally with overtones of "simpleton." With many variants (compare homebuddy, homeslice, both 1980s, with meaning shading toward "good friend"). The word had been used by Ruskin (1886) with the sense "stay-at-home male," and it was Canadian slang for "boy brought up in an orphanage or other institution" (1913).m Online Etymology :

"person from one's hometown," 1940s, American English, black slang, also originally with overtones of "simpleton." With many variants (cf. homebuddy, homeslice, both 1980s, with meaning shading toward "good friend"). The word had been used by Ruskin (1886) with the sense "stay-at-home male," and it was Canadian slang for "boy brought up in an orphanage or other institution" (1913).

According to one Google source, it originated during the mid 20th century, in Los Angeles, among the Mexican immigrant community, to refer to others who emigrated from one’s original geographical location. Today , it seems to also be used to designate those from a neighborhood, etc. There is also a source which states that it arose late 1800s to describe what we would call today a stay at home dad, or househusband. So….since its common usage today points primarily to the first, I would suppose that both are possible, but the second is archaic, and primarily dropped out of use before the second arose.

It’s a non-apostrophe contraction of hometown boy. Its origin seems to have been East Los Angeles, CA maybe in the 1970s or 1980s. It was later popularized in rap and hip-hop culture (more or less replacing the hackneyed term dude), as a way to identify locals whose reputations had grown via fame or infamy.

I heard that it was used in the military, celebrating those from one's hometown, when used in the form “homie”. Otherwise, it's a subtle put down, meaning some guy is afraid to venture outdoors from the security of his home.
The ghettos and Black people, or Black slang to be more precise. It means he comes from their neighborhood or the ghettos (commonly called the hood) in general.
The United States of America. Homeboy (noun) a male acquaintance from one’s own neighourhood or town. Or a member of a youth gang. (American)
